text: (relaxed music)
Thank you so much to "C&E News"
for including me among this group
of really impressive scientists.
It's also exciting to be in this session
of other chemical biologists.
So I'm gonna tell a few short stories
about binding drugs for difficult targets.
So, first a little bit about my, oops,
I clicked too many times.
First, a little bit about my background as has been,
oh, well, I guess this is gonna go quickly.
I grew up across the US.
And some early influences in science
are from family interest in birding,
and also I wanna thank my K-12 science teachers
for getting us to do controlled experiments
as early as fourth grade.
And I studied chemistry in Alanna Schepartz's lab at Yale.
I continued as a PhD student, Lu's lab at Harvard,
and then I was a postdoc in Kevan Shokat's lab at UCFS.
And now, as Lisa mentioned,
I'm a scientist at Novartis back in Cambridge.
So since it's a bit of a broad group,
I thought I'd take a couple of minutes
to talk about what is chemical biology,
especially because it's an interdisciplinary area
of research.
And the previous two talks were also great examples
of chemical biology research.
One definition I would say is that chemical biologists
use techniques from chemistry to study biology,
often with the goal of inventing new therapeutics.
And so to get a little bit more detail than this,
these are the questions that the groups that I trained in
were asking at the time that I joined.
So in the Schepartz lab,
I worked on a project that asked the question,
how can we introduce therapeutic proteins into the cell,
and how can we design therapeutic properties in them?
Cell likes to keep things out,
and so we successfully managed to get the cell
to take up some small peptides.
I'd say this is still an ongoing challenge in the field.
Now that we've gotten proteins in,
we realized the cell chews these things up
and they're no longer active.
So there are lots of people working on that still.
And at the time I joined David Lu's lab,
a lot of people were interested in the question,
what if we could perform evolution
on synthetic small molecules?
So in nature, we can see that evolution
has led to a huge diversity of form and function
in plants and animals.
And what if we could take this kind of powerful approach
and use it to impart new activities on synthetic compounds.
And I'll have a little bit more on that theme in a minute.
And then in Kevan's lab and actually continuing today,
I'm trying to answer the question,
how can we make drugs for difficult undrugged proteins?
So I briefly I want to introduce
the molecular players in this space.
Okay, what's happening?
All right.
So there are some key molecular players in chemical biology
and in the rest of my talk.
One is proteins.
So these are encoded by the genes
that you might've gotten a readout from 23andMe.
They could be inside the cell, outside the cell,
on the membrane of the cell.
And then for my purposes,
they're often responsible for driving a disease process.
The tool that we're going to use
to try to correct that disease process
are drug-like small molecules.
You can think of these as the active ingredient
in a pill that you might take.
And what we spend a lot of time doing
is trying to find an interaction
between the compound and the protein,
kind of like a key fitting into a lock.
And much like a key fitting into a lock,
you can either unlock the door or lock the door.
Small molecules, depending on their exact arrangement,
can cause different activities
in the proteins they interact with.
So in graduate school, the focus of my project
was trying to make a method to find new interactions
between proteins and small molecules as quickly as possible.
And so typically when you start a drug discovery campaign,
you might test 100,000 to a million compounds,
all in separate containers using sophisticated robots
that had their start in the automotive industry.
With DNA-encoded chemical libraries,
this process is miniaturized.
There's a barcode on each small molecule made out of DNA,
and then you can mix together your whole library,
and in fact, orders of magnitude
more than what you would screen individually,
and test up to in some cases up to 10 to the 10 compounds
for its ability to bind a single protein.
But of course, we're always interested in multiple proteins,
multiple diseases.
So we wondered what if we could perform
all of these experiments at once.
One experiment to test all the interactions
you might be interested in.
So we wanted to combine all of these different
protein-based DNA-encoded library experiments into one tube.
And so to do that, we put a DNA barcode
on the protein as well.
And so now if we get an binding interaction
between the protein and the small molecule,
sticky ends that we've engineered on the DNA
will bind to each other and make a new complex
that can be very quickly amplified by PCR,
which is really famous to everyone I think.
And this rapidly amplified piece of DNA also contains a code
for both the small molecule and the protein.
So when we used this method
to look at about 30,000 interactions all at once,
we identified several peaks here
which are the rapidly amplified DNA
corresponding to both new binding interactions
and binding interactions that we had spiked in.
So I think this is a really good example
of chemical biology
because we used a biological molecule, DNA,
to try to answer a question that's kind of at the center
of both chemistry and biology,
how do we identify new binding interactions.
It also made me more interested
in learning more about the details
of these small molecule protein binding interactions.
And so that's something that was the focus
of my project in the Shokat lab.
So when I joined the Shokat lab,
they were just a group of people
working on a protein called K-Ras,
which is a very infamous undrugged target.
And thanks to their efforts,
it's getting much, much closer to being drugged.
There's a lot of molecules under investigation right now.
But K-Ras mutations are responsible
for up to 200,000 different cases of cancer per year
in the US, across a range of tissues.
So Kevan and the group had noticed
that there are mutations that K-Ras acquires
that give it the ability to drive cancer.
And one of these mutations is to cystine,
abbreviated as cys.
Cystine is special for two reasons.
One it's not very common,
and two, it's more reactive than the other amino acids.
So they saw this as an opportunity
to form an irreversible reaction
with the new cystine on RAS,
And that allowed the team
to find a new binding pocket on RAS,
which allowed them to block the protein
in a way that was completely unexpected.
And that was really exciting
and inspired a lot of academics and industry work.
And is now the basis of these compounds
that are moving into the clinic.
One thing we noticed though is that unfortunately,
the cystine mutation is not very common.
A much more common mutation
in these oncogenic RAS proteins is aspartate.
And so the topic of my project
was to kind of hijack the chemical matter
that had been designed for targeting the cystine in K-Ras
and try to change the chemistry
so that we could try to react with this aspartate in RAS.
So I synthesized this panel of compounds,
and my first question was,
do any of these react with isolated aspartate in solution.
Under kind of idealized conditions,
I saw that two aziridines and two diazo groups
did efficiently react with aspartate.
The next question was,
can these compounds label purified K-Ras
with the aspartate mutation.
Unfortunately, even under kind of forcing
non-realistic pH conditions,
I did not see much reaction with aspartate on RAS.
So that was the end of my work on this project.
But I think that this is really still an active area
of investigation, probably for a lot of groups,
both targeting the aspartate on RAS
and other aspartates in general.
So now my last short story, as Lisa mentioned,
is in the field of targeted protein degradation.
This is a really an exploding area of chemical biology.
So this area in general asks the question,
can we make small molecules
that instead of opening or closing the lock,
just smash the lock altogether.
So it makes use
of the cells' normal protein recycling machinery.
When the cell wants to get rid of a protein,
what happens is that another protein called ubiquitin
is attached multiple times.
And this is the signal to the cell
that that protein should go to the proteasome
and get degraded or recycled
back into its component amino acids.
So in the last few years, chemical biologists realized
that they could make molecules here over the central arrow,
that recruit new proteins to the machinery
that does this ubiquitination function.
And that way you can ideally grab any protein
that you wanna get rid of in a particular disease,
and cause it to be degraded.
One thing that's interesting
is that there are over 600 different proteins
that are members of this complex
that are able to add ubiquitin to proteins.
But so far only two or three of them
have been used for targeted protein degradation.
So we wondered whether we make a method
that would help people quickly figure out
whether or not their protein could be degraded
by a new E3 ligase.
And so to do this,
we also made use of the special reactivity of cystine
to form an irreversible complex
between a new E3 ligase and an example,
a small molecule that binds to a known protein
that can be degraded as a test.
And then of course that can be extended.
So the goal here is to allow people to ask,
can this new E3 (indistinct)
and targeted protein degradation
before going through all the time-consuming work
of finding a new small molecule
to recruit that E3 ligase.
So we have a new pre-print and bio archive.
If you're interested, I urge you to check it out.
And here's just a little bit of proof of concept data
where we showed that we can successfully degrade a protein
called BRE4 using a known ligand for BRE4
attached to an E3 ligase called VHL.
And then if we add inhibitors
that either prevent the protease from acting
or prevent upstream ubiquitination steps,
we see the standard amount of BRE4 as before.
I forgot to mention that once we make this complex,
we need to get it into cells.
And we're doing that using a technique
called electroporation where you basically zap the cells,
make lots of little holes in the membrane,
and then the cell sucks up whatever is around it.
So with that,
I would like to thank a really large group of people,
and this is not exhaustive,
who I've had the privilege of working with
and being trained by over the years,
as well as some really generous funding agencies.
And thank you all for joining this virtual session.
Awesome, Thank you so much, Lynn,
for the great talk and sort of a walk through
some of the hot topics in chemical biology too,
that you've worked in over the course of your career.
I wanted to take a step back
and maybe we could just go back
to this idea of the new pre-print that has come out
in this last slide that you showed us.
Maybe you could talk a little bit about the way
that people had been making targeted protein degraders
in the past?
My impression is that's been using
a lot of elbow grease and trial and error.
It sounds like kind of you're helping
to put rational drug design into that process.
Maybe you could talk a little bit about that.
Yeah, so I think the first couple of E3 ligases
are the most popular ones that are used.
The chemical matter that recruits them
was kind of discovered serendipitously,
especially in one case.
And since this area has proven so fruitful,
now everyone's interested in trying to extend it
to more of the 3E ligases.
And you're right, that hopefully this will speed things up.
because the process of finding a new idea
and to recruit each of those E3 ligases
is very time-consuming.
So if we can have a shortcut to direct efforts
to the ones that are going to be productive,
hopefully that will help everybody.
So is the idea
that you then would have to kind of make a compound,
test it, see if that's working?
Instead you can kind of get ahead of time,
sort of take that shortcut?
Exactly. Yeah.
So some of these hijacking compounds
for targeted protein degradation have two pieces.
And that makes it maybe twice as time-consuming.
You need a piece
that recruits your target you wanna degrade.
And that recruits the enzyme you want to use to degrade it.
And so at least hopefully we can maybe shorten,
if you have now an option of 600 different things
to degrade that target,
how do you decide which one to go after?
And at least hopefully we can shortly that step.
I think I'll end with one last question
because it's interesting
to sort of look at how everyone's careers have progressed,
and how they've chosen
to work on different types of problems.
And I'll note that you've kind of gone from (indistinct)
to K-Ras and now protein degradation.
I'm curious, you're seeing kind of the full suite
of what's hot in drug discovery right now.
If there's an area that's your favorite,
or what has prompted you to sort of I guess
do this sampling.
Maybe you could talk a little bit about that.
Probably I have a short attention span.
If I go back to Stuart's talks in the morning,
maybe it's best to focus on one thing for 10 years
and really make strides in it.
So that's something to chew on.
But there's definitely lots of new, exciting areas,
that if you're a person with a short attention span,
you can go into for some time.
Do you find yourself learning from,
I guess are there pieces from one area that are helping you?
Or kind of ways that you solve problems
when you worked on a different type of chemical biology,
that's helping you as you say go into a different area?
Uh-oh, sorry.
I don't know if we had a delay issue.
But especially the first story and the third story
I think have a common theme of method development.
So there's definitely a way of thinking about that.
Of kind of prototyping something, testing it,
figuring out what area needs to be tweaked,
and kind of turning through that a little bit.
Wonderful.
Well, thank you so much, Lynn.
We were glad to have your talk and have you on our list.
